derivation.yuyuan_name: late 15th cent. (in sense 1 of the noun): from late Latin scapulare, from scapula 'shoulder'. The adjective (late 17th cent.) and the later senses of the noun are from scapula + -ar

means.word_mean: 1. a feather covering the shoulder of a bird
2. garment consisting of a long wide piece of woolen cloth worn over the shoulders with an opening for the head; part of a monastic habit
1. relating to or near the shoulder blade

auth_sentence.content: "Mamma mia," the abbess says, shifting her bosom indignantly beneath her scapular.
